Title: A Weekend on the Isle of Avalon
Summary:
Early Bird Discount: The first 6 attendees can save 10% with code AVALON2026.
Spring is just around the corner and with longer days and hopefully better weather on the way join us for a weekend in Somerset on the mystical Isle of Avalon. Steeped in legends, magic and mystery Glastonbury Tor is the centerpiece of King Arthur‚Äôs realm and¬†the heart of Avalon. Wells Cathedral and Wookey Hole Caves are nearby and there‚Äôs some great country walks to be had, so we won‚Äôt be short of things to do.
We‚Äôll be staying in nearby Street ‚Äì once occupied by the Romans Street is 2 miles south-west of Glastonbury and home to the Clarks Outlet Shopping village if you fancy a bit of bargain hunting too!
Accommodation:
Opened in 1931, YHA Street is the oldest YHA hostel still in operation today. It‚Äôs a quirky and compact Swiss-style chalet that‚Äôs surrounded by National Trust land and has recently been refurbished, with major improvements to all the communal areas, bedrooms and washing facilities, and has central heating.
Itinerary
Friday Evening:
Arrive, meet others and socialise, we‚Äôll have the usual Outdoor lads buffet, and possibly an evening activity followed by the¬†welcome meeting.
Saturday Day:
After breakfast (which is included in the event cost), we‚Äôll head out to visit Glastonbury, climb the tor, and relax at the
White Spring Sanctuary
. ¬†We'll aim for lunch in Glastonbury itself, so there should be options for sandwiches there.
Saturday Evening:
Dinner is included in the event cost, after which we may have an activity to join in if you wish.
Sunday:
After breakfast (included in the event cost) you are either free to go home or join in a possible activity such as a visit to the Wells Cathedral, and maybe end up at a local pub for a Sunday roast before heading home.
Dogs:
Sorry but the event is not suitable for dogs.
Want to Get Out More?
Why not check out the South Wales and South West Calendar
here
.
Difficulty & Distance: Mostly paths and lanes with a steep climb up Glastonbury Tor

Title: Bursledon to Netley and a Pink Ferry jaunt
Summary:
We start and finish our walk (see the route
here
) in the attractive leafy waterside village of Bursledon, from there we will walk almost entirely through woodlands to reach the Royal Victoria Country Park in Netley.
From Victoria Country Park, we can follow the England Coastal path that will have us reach ye ol Hamble - site of a centuries old historic ferry service, that is now operated as an on demand pink ferry. Before we call upon the ferry service, we will leave time for anyone in the group who would like to use the cafe for snacks.
You must bring ¬£2.50 cash for the ferry crossing.
We'll take the eastern banks of the River Hamble, following the path north, where the river path opens to big skies and low tide mud flats. A couple of kms along the path we can make time for another coffee break at the Hamble Universal Marina in Swannick.
The Hamble river path will take us to Swanwick Bridge - it is our crossing back to Burseldon and just a half mile further to return to the Burseldon Station.
Post walk for anyone who likes let's saunter to the celebrate pub named
The Jolly Sailor
at Bursledon.
Dogs:
I love having dogs on the walks I lead, and this walk is very suitable for them although there are some country lanes and suburban streets to walk along and roads to cross. A dog off its lead must be under control. The Pink Ferry allows dogs to ride free.
(All pictures taken by myself)
Difficulty & Distance: Distance is approximately 14 km (9 miles) and fairly flat;  terrain is dirt, grass and tarmac.

Title: A Bona Bijou Trollette Round Kenny's Latties
Summary:
A fantabulosa troll round town to vada the latties, boozers and boards where birthday boy Kenneth Williams minced, mused and moued (that's your actual French). Putting our best plates forward, we'll go round the Old Smoke to clock the pads he called home, and the places where he lapped up the dolly trade and the odd bevvy. You'll have to nish the chat while I do the palari at each place, so keep your minces peeled as we charper how the Smoke shaped him being bona ajax on the surface, but in a right two-and-eight deep down. So let's zhoosh up our riahs, put on some comfy bats, and stretch our lallies, because this mince will be fabulosa, and dead bona for a gaggle of fortuni omis like us.
The vadas and
troll
(please click the link at the Ordnance Survey website)
:
1. Russell Square Station:
Born on 22 February 1926 in Bingfield Street in King's Cross (now demolished), Bloomsbury was the spiritual home of Kenneth Williams. 'They needn‚Äôt talk to me about loneliness. I‚Äôve walked too many miles of pavement‚Ä¶' (
The Kenneth Williams Diaries,
21 April 1964)
2. 57 Marchmont Street, Bloomsbury:
Childhood home from 1935-1956. Mid-19th century terrace. ‚ÄúI never felt completely happy here, yet it shaped every odd, twisted impulse I have.‚Äù (
TKWD,
21 Apr 1964). His father ran a barber's shop on the ground floor. 'I remember once a man came into the shop and said "I'd like a blow wave, please" to which my father replied "you'll get no blow wave 'ere. What are you? An iron? Iron hoof? Not 'avin' any irons in my shop. Go on, get out!"¬†(
Kenneth Williams, Comic Roots
, 1983)
3. 14 Cromer House, Cromer Street, St Pancras:
Late Victorian block, 1880s. Grew up here with parents and sister (1925-1935). "When I was very young I used to throw a flower pots [from the balconies] on the heads of unsuspecting passersby, and one of them was Florrie Plume who happened to be a great friend of my mother's. She said afterwards ‚Äúit was the only by wearing a thick felt 'at at the time that saved me from a terrible injury from your boy‚Äù. My missile throwing was not the result of wickedness; it was simply because I suffered from insomnia and frankly I still do.' (
Kenneth Williams: Going Places
, 1975)
4. The Boot Pub, Cromer Street:
Late Georgian pub, 1820s. Early comic training ground doing comic songs and routines and listening to the stories and accents of patrons. 'I found that if I got up on the stage to entertain the troops I could make them shut up and look.' (Quote c. 1960s).
5. Argyle Primary School, Tonbridge Street:
Victorian school, 1870s. Early education and first stage notice. ‚ÄúAs a scholar my results were lamentable except for English because I liked the English master. He would take out take us reading poetry every day - Shakespeare, Tennyson, Browning - and he directed me in the school play...it was called the Rose and the Ring, and they gave me a big part as the Princess Angelica. I stomped around the stage waving my feather duster and saying "get out of my way!". I had no idea how aristocrats behaved, but I think I did it instinctively. I got a very good notice in the local paper which pleased me immensely. It was my first taste of performing. It read: "Kenneth Williams, with his mincing step and comical demeanour as the Princess Angelia was a firm favourite for the audience to whom his pert vivacity made great appeal."' (
Kenneth Williams, Comic Roots
, 1983)
6. Endsleigh Court:
A mid-20th century Bloomsbury mansion block. His first independent home (1956‚Äì59).
7. Marlborough House, Osnaburgh Street:
19th-century townhouse (demolished). Lived here from 1970 until his death on 14 April 1988. 'Providing there is no pain I shall be happy to go when the time comes; nothing here has really delighted me except Art.' (
TKWD,
22 January 1985)
8. Regent‚Äôs Park ‚Äì Outer Circle / Queen Mary‚Äôs Gardens:
John Nash, 1811‚Äì1820. 'I walked here often, alone with my thoughts. The roses seemed to judge me gently, not mock me.' ¬†(
TKWD
, 20 March 1988)
9. Farley Court, Baker Street
Edwardian block, 1905. Lived here from 1963 to 1970. ‚ÄúI sometimes wonder where I learned all the rubbish ‚Äòbeliefs‚Äô I used to hold‚Ä¶ the only way to execute & convey your vision‚Ä¶ is to do it yourself.' (
TKWD
). Nearby is Madame Tussaud's and the Planetarium (1958).
10. BBC Broadcasting House, Portland Place:
Art Deco building by George Val Myer, 1932. It was here that some of his greatest radio successes -
Beyond Our Ken
,
Round the Horne
,
Just a Minute
- were recorded. 'They needn‚Äôt talk to me about loneliness. I‚Äôve walked too many miles of pavement‚Ä¶' (
TKWD,
21 April 1964). Nearby is all Souls Church (John Nash, 1823) and the RIBA headquarters (George Grey Wornum, 1934).
11. Garrick Theatre, Charing Cross Road:
Designed by W.G.R. Sprague, 1889. Location of revues, such as
Pieces of Eight
and
Share My Lettuce
. ¬†'Last performance of
Share My Lettuce
‚Ä¶ a wonderful last night house.' (
TKWD,
17 May 1958)
12. Stanfords, Long Acre (Site):
19th-century building, rebuilt 1920s. Early draughtsman job as a mapmaker. 'The thing to do, in any circumstance, is to appear to know exactly what you are doing.' (
TKWD,
c1964)
13. Russell Square:
1804, Laid out by the Dukes of Bedford. 'Squares of learning and quiet; I envied the calmness of stone as I carried my restless mind past.' (
TKWD
)
14.
Finish at Russell Square Station.

Title: Hull Bouldering - All Abilities (beginners welcome)
Summary:
Swap trainers for climbing shoes and join OutdoorLads for a day of INDOOR BOULDERING at RockCity in Hull.
If you haven't been to RockCity before, please head to
their website
to complete the membership form and purchase a Peak Day Pass before coming to the centre.
What is Bouldering?
It's a form of climbing where instead of long high routes, the 'problems' tend to be shorter and focus on technique, balance, body positioning and sometimes power. Because of this different emphasis, bouldering doesn't have the hassle of climbing with ropes, harnesses and belaying, which makes it an excellent activity for newcomers to the sport. No wonder it's often regarded as the 'purest' form of climbing.
If you're a seasoned climber you won't need convincing about the benefits of bouldering, but for those who've never climbed more than a staircase, the benefits are wide ranging: from the physical - improved strength, tone, balance, power and coordination; mental - problem solving, focus, concentration and body awareness; to the emotional - relaxation, a sense of achievement and a feeling that mind and body are working together perfectly ('feeling psyched'). On top of all this, bouldering tends to be a very social sport where you can hang out with mates and each have a go as you feel regardless of what level you climb at.
I'm new to Bouldering - can I come along?
If you have never tried bouldering before it is recommended that you have a guided session from the event leader, who will go through everything you will need to know to boulder safely before joining in with the rest of the group.
I've been Bouldering before?
As above, everyone attending the event¬† must abide by the centre's T&Cs etc. As an experienced boulderer you responsible¬†for your own safety, actions and involvement at all times. As such, you should use your own judgement in taking up advice given either by OutdoorLads Volunteers or other experienced climbers.
Don't forget to join us in the evening for the
Hull Social
Photos : Copyright granted to OutdoorLads by the event leader / venue.
You¬†MUST¬†complete a
Participation Statement
,
in addition
to booking your event space¬†before¬†attending an OutdoorLads event. You only need to complete this Participation Statement once, not for each event you attend.
Please note that every person participating should be aware of (and accept) that those members perceived as ‚Äòin charge‚Äô or leading the event are not necessarily qualified, do not need to be qualified, and are not regarded by OutdoorLads, or themselves as ‚Äòtechnical experts‚Äô but are amateur climbers with some experience and who are happy to impart their knowledge. Any advice given should be considered with this in mind by the recipient.
All those attending the event must also be aware of the centre's own terms and conditions of participation and abide by them, along with any instructions given by the centre‚Äôs staff. Everyone must also take responsibility for their own safety while participating in Indoor climbing events.
Difficulty & Distance: Suitable for all abilities. If you're new to bouldering, just let the event leader know and we'll get you started!

Title: Mapledurham Minimal Mud Midwinter Meander
Summary:
Waitlist
:
If this event becomes fully booked, but if you'd like to attend,
please add yourself to the waitlist.
Places often become available closer to the date, and you are likely to get one.
Start the new year with a refreshing adventure with a bracing (or wet!) figure of eight 11-mile winter hike from Reading Station, into my local 'hood' and reaching out into the fringes of the Chiltern countryside. With the days still short and the air crisp (or moist!), this is a good way to shake off the post-holiday slump and reconnect with nature ‚Äî and each other.
The Route:
We‚Äôll quickly leave the bustle of Reading's town centre behind, finding the Thames Path, using the millennial pedestrian Christchurch bridge to cross over into Caversham and continue along the river through the Christchurch Meadows. After a busy road junction we escape into quiet suburbia starting with a quick stop at Caversham court and then through Caversham Heights, home of yours truly, and if there are any fans of Coronation Street please let me know and I can point something out!!
From Caversham Heights we continue North and West across the South Oxfordshire and Chiltern Hills boundaries, largely walking through the Mapledurham estate which includes a golf course, farm and parkland. We will get a view of the front of Mapledurham House as we proceed towards the village of Mapledurham, where we will stop for lunch by the churchyard and you can also get a glimpse of Mapledurham water mill.
As this can be a muddy time of the year this walk optimizes on tarmac and concrete lanes, but still with some brief dirt sections which are likely to be muddy. Towards the end of the walk, as we return back to Caversham and Reading, there are several options to have a beer or coffee/tea and cake and we can figure out what the group would like to do on the day.
The route can be found
here
:
Dogs:
Well-behaved dogs are welcome, there are minimal stiles on route but are a few sections where we will be walking in parks and urban areas where they will need to be on a lead. Please abide by the Countryside Code (
https://tinyurl.com/rlqvp3h
) and remember¬†not everyone loves¬†dogs as much as you do so be mindful of other members.
The Sights:
Reading:
we won't see a lot of Reading on this walk, but with a population larger than many cities it's now the largest town in the UK. On the gaydar it has associations with Oscar Wilde who went to prison in Reading Jail (hence the poem Ballad of Reading Gaol), the victorian walls of which are now adorned with a Banksy. Reading Station is one of the busiest outside of London and was heavily re-built in 2015, and became a terminus of the Elizabeth Line when this opened in 2022. The swanky new development opposite the station is called Station Hill (only phase 1 is currently complete) and made headline news in 2023 when there was a big fire in one of the towers whilst still under construction.
Christchurch Meadows:
is a large public park in situated on the north bank of the River Thames, opposite the town centre, and features wide grassy areas, mature trees and a Riverside path.
Caversham:
is Reading suburb, located just north of the Thames, and has a distinct village-like atmosphere with a busy high street offering independent shops, caf√©s, and restaurants, along with several parks and riverside walks. In years gone by it would have been part of Oxfordshire and separate to Reading in Berkshire, as with some towns and villages along the Thames the river acts as the county boundary.
Caversham Court Gardens:
is a historic public garden. Set on the site of a former medieval manor house, the grade II gardens feature landscaped lawns, mature trees, riverside walks and the remains of old terraces and walls.
Mapledurham:
is a large parish adjoining Caversham, with the main village itself being a few miles into the countryside and feels a million miles away the bustle of Reading, being practically traffic free at the end of a no-through road. It is primarily an estate village with all of the houses formerly linked to the estate. It‚Äôs best known for its historic
Mapledurham House
, an Elizabethan manor, built in 1585, and the home of the Blount family for 400 years and is still privately owned by their descendants. The house has featured in T
he Eagle Has Landed
(1976) and
Midsomer Murders
. ¬†Adjacent to the house and also part of the estate is
Mapledurham Watermill
, the last operational watermill on the Thames, which still produces flour today. For music fans, the mill appeared on the front cover of Black Sabbath's debut album in 1970.
Unfortunately neither the house or watermill are open to the public in the winter, but if you are inspired to return they are open during the summer months.
Is this your first ODL event?
Attending your first event with OutdoorLads might feel daunting.¬†What will¬†happen, who will be there, and what can you¬†expect? We know that new members in particular like to know in advance more about what an OutdoorLads event will be like.
If this is your first ODL event, you should check out the information designed specifically for you on the
My First Event
page on the ODL website
.
If you have any other questions you can send a message to the leader.
All photos taken by the leader and permission given to OutdoorLads for use.
Difficulty & Distance: 11 mile (18km) hike, mainly on tarmac and concrete paths and lanes but a few dirt stretches. A couple of hills with a total ascent of 200 meters

Title: Reading New Year Drop By Brunch/Coffee Social
Summary:
This is a casual drop in for brunch or coffee in central Reading which can be combined with the 'Mapledurham Minimal Mud Midwinter Meander' hike event which follows or you can join as a stand alone event if you just happen to be in Reading on this date. There will be no table booking, so just turn up between 09:30 and 10:50 and I'll be there at least. You can have brunch (come by 10 am if you plan to join the walk to allow time) or maybe just come along for a coffee or tea (drop by before 10:20).
The Shed is a small independent cafe, LGBT+ friendly, which is located in a narrow street now dwarfed by the Station Hill development construction, just a few minutes walk from Reading Railway Station. You order and pay as you enter and then go upstairs and the food/drink will be bought to the table.
New Members
Please feel free to join this as your first OutdoorLads event.¬†If you have any questions then feel free to message me, or go to the "My First Event" section under "About Us".

This venue is not suitable for dogs.

Summary:
Our monthly London pub socials are the perfect gateway to Outdoor Lads and our busy diary of brilliant events. For February, we're returning to The Rising in Elephant & Castle!
If you‚Äôre feeling hungry and fancy a bite, The Rising partners with Yard Sale Pizza, so you can order delicious pizzas to enjoy on the premises. They‚Äôll even provide plates and cutlery.
Typically our socials have a rich mix of regulars, occasionals, and newbies, not only from London and the South East, but dropping in from across the country.
Whether it's hiking, camping, cycling, climbing, or a range of other activities - we do it!¬† Outdoors is our focus, but our socials are the chance to catch up with lads you've already met, find out about the group, and meet new members and event leaders.

Title: BIRMINGHAM Indoor Climbing - MONDAY - Beginners
Summary:
Join OutdoorLads for an evening of indoor climbing & bouldering at Redpoint Birmingham Climbing Centre.
*** BEGINNER (supervised) events are offered every two weeks ***
If you have never climbed before (or need a refresher on the basics), then this BEGINNERS EVENT is ideal for you! I will happily show you the ropes & teach you everything you need to know to climb safely!
Event pages are split into
BEGINNER & EXPERIENCED.
Please ensure you sign up to the correct event as only two beginners are allowed to be signed in to be supervised per leader.
This event is for beginner climbers (those needing to be supervised) only!
If you are competent with how to tie in & belay (safely & confidently), then you will need to
sign up to the accompanying experienced (independent climber) event
instead.
Bouldering
- Whilst most of us do roped climbing, if you prefer to do bouldering, you can sign yourself in & go bouldering (unsupervised) instead of, or as well as, roped climbing. Please meet the leader & the group at the start though; some others might wish to do bouldering too!
Please note that we will not teach lead climbing or lead belaying on this event -
we would suggest having some
lessons in Lead Climbing
by a qualified member of staff if this is something you're interested in pursuing!
If the event is full, please join the waiting list. If other leaders are able to attend, I may be able to increase numbers.
If you are subsequently unable to attend, please cancel off the event. Spaces for beginners are limited & 'no-shows' are frustrating for the leader & other attendees.
Redpoint Birmingham Climbing Centre
Indoor climbing centres offer the challenges of climbing that you'll find on natural rock crags - simply indoors! It's a fun way to stay fit, make new friends & develop your climbing skills.
Climbing
- Unlike Indoor Bouldering there is a certain amount of skill to be mastered, such as tying in knots & belaying a partner, as well as the climbs being higher than in bouldering.¬†If you are new to climbing (or would like a refresher), there are plenty of top-rope routes to choose from after learning the essential climbing & safety techniques with one of our friendly, experienced climbing leaders.
Bouldering
-¬†Instead of tackling long high routes, the 'problems' (as they are referred to) are shorter & focus on technique, balance, body positioning & sometimes power.¬†With the different emphasis, bouldering doesn't have the hassle of climbing with ropes, so it‚Äôs excellent (but not necessarily easier) for newcomers.
Redpoint Birmingham Climbing Centre
has more than 75 lines with over 300 routes, set through some spectacular ground including its notorious 'stalactite'. It even features one of the few indoor 'Yorkshire VS cracks' in the country, to test your jamming skills. The¬†bouldering rooms are just as interesting as its climbing routes, over 200 bouldering problems have been organised into graded circuits to provide something for everyone.
You MUST register via this event page before coming to the centre!

Title: Skiing and Snowboarding - Snozone, Castleford
Summary:
Get ready for the ski season with a refresher at Snozone, Yorkshire's indoor snow centre. It offers real snow skiing and snowboarding for all ages and abilities. With a dedicated snow school for adaptive lessons, it‚Äôs perfect for beginners and pros alike.
In order to book a pass for the main slope you will need to have skied or snowboarded before and be able to
link turns, control speed, use a button lift and fit boots correctly.
Any main slope users not meeting these requirements will be asked to vacate the slope.
We will be booking two hour passes starting at 7pm. The cost of this is ¬£39.99 (if you prefer, you can book a 1 hour pass for ¬£35.99)
Please book your pass in advance on the Snozone website.
Don't leave it too late as slots are unlikely to be available at the last minute,
The price includes the hire of boots, helmet, skis or snowboard and ski poles. Clothing (jacket and trousers) can be hired separately if you don't have it, and gloves and socks can be purchased if required - see the¬†'What Kit to Bring¬†'section.
If you are not a competent skier or would prefer to book some refresher lessons, you are still welcome to come along but you will need to book a lesson (various options for
group and private lessons
for skiers and boarders of all abilities can be booked through the Snozone website)
Please note that you need to book direct with Snozone for your participation for this event, and must comply with their terms and conditions. OutdoorLads is merely organising for the group to be there together to add a social element to the experience.
Photos:
all images supplied by OutdoorLads leaders. OutdoorLads has permission to use them.

European Snow Pride
and
European Gay Ski Week
, Have you booked your place yet?

Title: Hull Social February 2026 Social
Summary:
Join us as we return to ¬†one of the National Geographic "Top 10 places to visit in 2026"
Hull is rich in culture, with stunning museums; art galleries; cream phone boxes; Europe's largest 'submarium' (complete with Sharks); old bars that played host to the beginning of the English Civil War and the backdrop for many TV and film productions (Victoria, The Crown, A Royal Night out, Enola Holmes). ¬†The city also has a buzzing gay scene in the newest Freedom Quarter, which hosts multiple gay bars and clubs.
We will be organising several other events in the area over the weekend, including an early Saturday walk; indoor climbing and a cultural walk around Hull. Keep an eye on this page for updates.
The venue for the social has not yet been confirmed and is subject to change.
Although the event officially ends at 10pm, it is likely that some of us will end up in a late night bar, such as Broadway show bar or firebox (usually open until 6am).
This is a fantastic opportunity to meet new people or catch up with existing friends. All are welcome.

,
in addition
to booking your event space¬†before¬†attending an OutdoorLads event. You only need to complete this Participation Statement once, not for each event you attend.

Title: A Railway, a River and a Rabbit
Summary:
A Valentine's Day hike to get your heart racing!
This hike will start and finish in Arundel. There will be a good mix of scenery and views across the Sussex countryside. A few reasonable ups and downs and also pleasant flat ground await us as we enjoy some history and landmarks.
Click on this
Link
to view the route (opens OS Maps)
A Few Features:
River Arun
One of the fastest flowing rivers in England this river will accompany us for most of the hike. It is the longest river in Sussex and is tidal some 25 miles inland from Littlehampton. It's safe to assume that many of the villages and hamlets we pass through chose their location due to the river. Major improvements were made to the river as far back as 1540 when Arundel became a port.
Arun Valley Railway Line
A much loved railway route offering great views of the Sussex countryside. As with the river the railway line will be with us for the hike. This route was one of the last in the area to be upgraded to modern colour light signalling, having previously been controlled by semaphore signals. The route also now uses axile counters to monitor the passage of trains. It sounds primitive but is meant to be fail safe. It works by train wheels being counted into a section of track and then counted out as it leaves. As long as they match then it's safe for the train behind to move forward.
Burpham Church
A church was recorded as being here in the Domesday book. The current tower dates to around the 15th century. We should hear the bells as they ring out every 15 minutes. There are records of bells being installed as early as 1488 when the vicar gave 12p towards purchasing them.
North Stoke
A medieval village first recorded in 1086. A sparce population meant that in 1931 the parish was merged with neighbouring Amberley. A few houses remain and a church that is maintained by volunteers.
South Stoke
This village now falls under the Parish of Houghton but is part of the wider area of Offham. The Domesday book listed South Stoke as having 14 households and a church valued at ¬£4. The population declined to medieval levels in 1806. This was due to common land being enclosed for Arundel Park. This in turn took away places for the local population to graze sheep and livestock.
The Black Rabbit
On our return leg we'll stop at this lovely pub for a break. It's a renowned location offering views of Arundel Castle, the river and the wetlands beyond. Inside the pub boasts authentic props from the Harry Potter movies.
Arundel Castle
Although not part of this hike we will have views of the castle. It is a stunning restored medieval castle that is steeped in history. A couple of highlights include the castle being besieged by troops loyal to Henry I in 1101 and extensive damage being caused during the English Civil War.
Dogs:
I love having dogs on my walks. I just ask that owners please ensure they are kept on a lead as appropriate, especially around livestock and when near busy roads. Please, also remember that not everyone is a dog lover.
Don‚Äôt Waste That Space!
Walks get filled up quite quickly, so please only sign up if you know you are free to attend. Plans do sometimes change, but remember to free up your space so someone else can attend.
New Members:
If this is your first event or you are new to OutdoorLads we‚Äôd love to see you. Please message me if you have any questions.
Looking For More:
Check out this
Link
for details of other walks taking place in the South East.
Check out this
Link
for details of provisional upcoming events in the ODL diary.
(All photos taken by the leader and permission is given for OutdoorLads to reuse them.)
Difficulty & Distance: Distance is 15.70 km (9.75 miles); total ascent is 192 metres; terrain is tarmac, dirt, grass and woodland paths. Expect areas of mud and some puddles.

Title: NOTTINGHAM Indoor Climbing ‚Äì THURSDAY ‚Äì Beginners Welcome
Summary:
Join OutdoorLads at Nottingham Climbing Centre
Climbing evenings are held regularly and we tend to go to the local pub ‚Äì The Lion for refreshments and a social gathering afterwards where they have a wide variety of beverages both alcoholic and non-alcoholic.
NOTE: If you are climbing with us for the first time
, either as an experienced climber or beginner, please send a note to the
Event Leader
telling them about your experience and goals. There is a limit to the number of beginners that we can accommodate at each session. Each beginner needs to be supervised so we need to ensure there are enough experienced climbers to help you out. Climbing is great fun! It's a fab workout, in a social environment, and anyone can do it! Give it a go!
Nottingham Climbing Centre
Nottingham Climbing Centre is equipped with walls and routes to suit all skill levels and groups of climbers, whether you are a novice looking to try climbing for the first time, or an experienced lead climber, you‚Äôll find an area to challenge you. With 28 Top Ropes routes available as well as 24 Lines of Lead climbing for the more advanced individuals. In addition, 6 auto-belays are available, so there is always the opportunity to climb, even if the numbers don‚Äôt match up. The available bouldering walls also provide that extra physical and mental challenge for those looking for something slightly different from rope work. Both Bouldering and Rope Climbing routes range from 4a ‚Äì 8a.
I'm new to Climbing - can I come along?
If you've never climbed before or need a refresher, the leader will sign you into the climbing centre as a
supervised climber
so that you can come and give it a try (it can be helpful to message the leader to let them know). If you enjoy your climbing experience, and would like to come climbing more regularly, we will also happily show you the ropes and teach you everything you need to know to climb safely.
Do I need to be Supervised as a Climber?
If you answer
NO
to any of the following three questions, then you will need to arrange to be supervised. If you can answer YES to all these questions, you can sign up to this event as normal:
Can you fit a climbing harness correctly?
Can you tie yourself to the end of a rope using the correct knots?
Can you belay another climber correctly and confidently?
To come along, you will need to register via this event page and to climb you will need to pay an entry fee directly to the climbing centre when you arrive, please see their
website
for up-to-date prices. We ask that all members sign up through the event page to make sure the event leader has all information of the members attending.
To climb at Nottingham Climbing Centre you will need to:
-‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇComplete a climbing waiver for the centre (please arrive early to do this the first time, or better still complete it online before you arrive)
-‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇPay the Lifetime Registration Fee - ¬£6.00
-‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇPay an Entry Fee directly to the climbing centre - ¬£9.50 (ensure you mention ODL)
-‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇHire shoes (if you don‚Äôt have your own) - ¬£3.50*
-‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇHire a harness (again, if you don‚Äôt have your own) - ¬£3.50*
-‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇHire shoes and harness - ¬£6.00*
*Equipment hire charges will be waived for your first visit to the centre!
Can I just come along and boulder?
Absolutely! Most of us do roped climbing, but if you prefer bouldering, you can sign yourself in and do it, as long as you can fill in the climbing centre's form correctly, watch their
safety video
and can answer the simple safety questions at reception on your first visit. Meet the group at the start; some others might be bouldering. We will make sure we come and find you when we have our tea break!
If you have any questions or need any more information just get in touch with the event leader by clicking on their profile below, or take a look at the
My first climbing event page
for more information.
IMPORTANT! - Participation Statement
You MUST complete a
Participation Statement
, in addition to booking your event space before attending an OutdoorLads event. You only need to complete this Participation Statement once, not for each event you attend.
Anyone with COVID-19 symptoms, even if they are extremely mild, or who has recently tested positive for Covid-19, is asked not to attend.

All images supplied by event leaders and used by OutdoorLads with permission.
Difficulty & Distance: Beginners welcome.

Title: January Retreat to the North Devon Coast
Summary:
Join Ben for a quiet and relaxed weekend on the North Devon Coast.
This early year weekend is the perfect chance to¬†get some fresh sea air in peaceful countryside. ¬†OutdoorLads hostels are a great way to quickly meet new friends and find out about what we do.¬†Attending your first hostel event could be a daunting experience if you don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs going to happen so why not have a read of our '
My First Hostel Event
' guide.
Yenworthy is a fully accessible hostel hidden away in a wooded valley on the outskirts of Exmoor making for¬†a warm and comfortable retreat from the depths of Winter. ¬†With three rooms to socialise in along with an undercover area outside and a fire pit area there's plenty of space to play board games or chat away and make new friends aswell as catching up with old ones over the weekend.
NUT FREE SiTE
- Our hostel provider has asked that
no nuts
are to be brought onto the site.
Friday evening:
Arrive, settle in and meet with fellow ODLers. ¬†A simple evening meal (included in the event cost) will be provided followed by a welcome meeting. ¬†The rest of the evening is yours to enjoy.
Saturday:
After breakfast (included in the event cost) we'll head out for an 8 mile walk taking in the South West Coast Path. You will need a relatively good level of fitness for the walk.
Please bring a packed lunch
and maybe a flask of hot drink if it's cold.
If you don't fancy coming on the walk, you can choose to stay in the hostel or explore nearby Lynton and Porlock Weir.
Saturday evening:
Relax and socialise or help out preparing the 2 course evening meal (included in the event cost) which we'll all enjoy.
Sunday
After breakfast we'll help clean and tidy away leaving the hostel as we found it. ¬†After that you can explore the North Devon Coast.
ACCESIBILITY:
As mentioned this hostel is accessible to wheelchair users, with a hoist system available in some rooms and we have the ability to make additional arrangements to support a carer attending if needed. ¬†This means that whilst our walk along the coastal path might not be suitable, we would love to offer the opportunity to attend to someone that might not normally be able to join Outdoorlads events. ¬†If this is you please reach out to
support@outdoorlads.com
so we can ensure we can cater to all of your needs.
Photo Credits:
All photos taken by OutdoorLads Members and permission is granted to OutdoorLads for further use.
Difficulty & Distance: ODL Hostel Events are always fun and there is no pressure to take part in the Day Walk

Title: Indoor Climbing on Tour - Stockport (Experienced Climbers)
Summary:
Over the next few months Outdoor Lads will be touring some of the Northwest's favourite climbing centres, this event being in south-east Manchester.
This event is intended as a safe space for the LGBTQ+ community; everyone will be warmly welcomed.
Our indoor climbing events offer a fantastic way to get fit, have fun, and challenge yourself in a supportive and social environment.
Located within the old engine house of Pear mill in Lower Bredbury, on the edge of Stockport, the
Awesome Walls
climbing centre has¬†over 100 lines of climbing available (including it's famous 23.5m "Tall Walls"¬† - one of the highest artificial climbing walls in England!!)¬†as well as an extensive bouldering area! With grades for all abilities any climber will enjoy the routes here.
To come along, you will need to register via this event page¬†and to climb you will need to pay an entry fee directly to the climbing centre when you arrive, please see their
website
for their price (OutdoorLads members qualify for the concessionary rate).¬†It is important that all members sign up through the event page to make sure the event leader has all information of the members attending.
I'm new to Climbing - can I come along?
If you've never climbed before but want to give it a try - then OutdoorLads run a weekly event in Manchester (and many other cities across the country!) where we're more than happy to show you the ropes ¬†and teach you everything you need to know to climb safely, but unfortunately this event is for climbers who do not need to be supervised - and allows our volunteer leader to push themselves a little more. Therefore, if you answer
NO
to any of the following three questions, then please check out some of our other
local climbing events
which will be more suitable for you;
Can you fit a climbing harness correctly?
Can you tie in to a rope using the correct knots?
Can you belay another climber correctly and confidently?
What other Climbing events do OutdoorLads Run?
We run regular indoor climbing and bouldering events across the North West -
Click here
to see all the current events.

Sieh
.
Difficulty & Distance: Suitable for experienced climbers

Title: Bristol Indoor Bouldering - all abilities welcome!
Summary:
The Climbing Academy is one of the best bouldering centres in the South West. With over 200 problems in a 750 square metre area there is enough to keep even the avid of boulderers occupied.
Bouldering is a form of climbing where instead of long high routes, the 'problems' as they are referred to tend to be shorter and focus on technique, balance, body positioning and sometimes power. Because of this different emphasis, bouldering doesn't have the hassle of climbing with ropes, harnesses and belaying, which makes the activities excellent for newcomers to the sport. For this reason, it is often regarded as the 'purest' form of climbing.
If you're a seasoned climber you won't need convincing about the benefits of bouldering, but for those who've never climbed more than a staircase, the benefits are wide ranging: from the physical - improved strength, tone, balance, power and coordination; mental - problem solving, focus, concentration and body awareness; to the emotional - relaxation, a sense of achievement and a feeling that mind and body are working together perfectly ('feeling psyched'). On top of all this, bouldering tends to be a very social sport where you can hang out with mates and each have a go as you feel regardless of what level you climb at.
This event is for members of all levels of experience and all are welcome to come along to any of the sessions.
To come along, you will need to register via the event page, and to climb you will need to pay an entry fee directly to the centre when you arrive. For entry fee prices go to:
https://www.theclimbingacademy.com/prices/
. As we start at 8pm you will pay the off-peak price.
For your first time climbing with us, especially if you are a novice climber, please contact the event leader in advance to let him know what your skills and experience are.
It is important that all members sign up through the event page to make sure the event leader has all information of the members attending.
Climbing and Bouldering¬†Participation statement
Please note that every person participating should be aware of (and accept) that those members perceived as ‚Äòin charge‚Äô or leading the event are not necessarily qualified, do not need to be qualified, and are not regarded by OutdoorLads, or themselves as ‚Äòtechnical experts‚Äô but are amateur climbers with experience and who are happy to impart their knowledge. Any advice given should be considered with this in mind by the recipient.
All those attending the event must also be aware of the centre's own terms and conditions of participation and abide by them, along with any instructions given by the centre's staff. Everyone must also take responsibility for their own safety while participating in Indoor climbing events.
Want to Get Out More?
To be informed of all our South West events please click on this Telegram link
http://outdoorlads.events/SouthWestNotifications
Please see our website for more
information including an FAQ
about our¬†events.

Title: Liverpool Games night
Summary:
Yes ITS BACK!!
Join us for a different kind of night out!
Sugar & Dice is an independent board game caf√© in the Baltic Triangle area of Liverpool City Centre.
When you visit, you have full access to the huge library of card and board games. Just find your favourite games, and get going.
If you're not sure where to start, all of Sugar and Dices staff are massive board game fans and they'd love to show you how to play their favourite games.
You can also enjoy our delicious selection of food and homemade cakes while you play.
There's a small cover charge of ¬£2 per person, per hour. This is paid separate at the end
We will play as a group and the booking will be made for 6 people and confirmed with the venue.
You will be asked to confirm your place the weekend before to ensure that the table is reserved for the right numbers. If anyone drops out after the booking is made the leader will end up paying and will jeopardise the event running again. ¬†Please take this into account when booking a spot
Social events are great way to forge new friendships and talk about your experiences on OutdoorLads events, and to find out what is going on in the coming months.

Title: Run Every Day (RED) January 2026 - Banish the winter blues!
Summary:
Help combat the winter blues by running every day in January. If you‚Äôre anything like me, then going for a run is the last thing you want to do...¬†even though you know releasing endorphins is good for your mental health... apparently...
Join me (virtually) in running every day in January - plus a bit of February if you've not quite managed to get started yet!¬† (Thanks to
IanVonLux
for setting up the original!)
The idea is (Shamelessly stolen from
Marcothon
!):
Run every day for a month from when you join us
(so January and maybe a bit of February - plenty of us have perhaps had a cold over Christmas or just been slow at starting our New Year's Resolutions :) )
Pick your own distance
...it's about what will be an achievable challenge for you, it might be a mile, it might be a marathon, or it might be
Couch to 5K
(great app for people starting out).
It's a personal challenge
- if you think you‚Äôre cheating then you probably are.
Extra bonus points for
running in nature
.¬† Not that points mean prizes or anything :)
No cycling, rowing or climbing the stairs in your house
.¬† It's not really a walking challenge as such either but if you do need to walk a bit during your run to get your breath back nobody is watching...
You can run on a treadmill
if that's your thing (or the weather is rubbish) though.
The pace isn‚Äôt important,
this isn‚Äôt a race
.
Parkruns
very much encouraged
(but not compulsory) - why not keep an eye on the ODL website and see if we're doing one as a group near you?
It's the taking part that counts here - although you should be sure of your own fitness/ability in taking on this challenge, don‚Äôt injure yourself if you‚Äôre not used to running, and don't be afraid to miss a day and make up for it later if you're genuinely a bit injured (rather than just not feeling like it :) ), it's the effort that counts!
We are mostly chatting and encouraging each other on the following Telegram group:
https://t.me/+Q8U5IAIN1KY5Y2M0
You may also wish to sign up to the
Strava OutdoorLads running club:
https://www.strava.com/clubs/439735
Don't worry if you missed the 1st, you can join (or start) a bit later in January and finish in February if you wish, completely up to you, we will stick around and support you either way!¬† If you've found this event page after 1st and still want to join that's cool, just join the above groups and say hello, and don't worry about the event itself!
Images are provided under creative commons licence from
https://pixabay.com/service/license/
and used according to their license agreement.
Difficulty & Distance: Pace or distance is less important than turning up every day

Title: BIRMINGHAM Indoor Climbing - MONDAY - Experienced
Summary:
Join OutdoorLads for an evening of indoor climbing & bouldering at Redpoint Birmingham Climbing Centre.
"EXPERIENCED" in this instance is those that have previously climbed & can answer YES to all three of these questions:
Can you fit a climbing harness correctly?
Can you tie in to a rope using the correct knots?
Can you belay another climber correctly &¬†confidently?
Please ensure you only sign up for this event if you
satisfy all three of the prerequisites as an experienced (independent) climber!
Never climbed before? Need a refresher on the basics? Answered NO to any of the three questions above? You will need to
attend a beginners (supervised) event
instead, where we will happily sign you in to be supervised (two people per leader maximum), show you the ropes & teach you everything you need to know to climb safely! ¬†Beginner (supervised) events are offered every two weeks only; this enables the event leader to climb too.
Bouldering
- Whilst most of us do roped climbing, if you prefer to do bouldering, you can sign yourself in & go bouldering (unsupervised) instead of, or as well as, roped climbing. Please meet the leader & the group at the start though; some others might wish to do bouldering too!
Please note that we will not teach lead climbing or lead belaying on this event -
we would suggest having some
lessons in Lead Climbing
by a qualified member of staff if this is something you're interested in pursuing!
Whilst this event finishes at 8pm, the centre is open until 10pm if you wish to continue climbing for longer!
If you are subsequently unable to attend, please cancel off the event as 'no-shows' are frustrating for the leader & other attendees.
Redpoint Birmingham Climbing Centre
Indoor climbing centres offer the challenges of climbing that you'll find on natural rock crags - simply indoors! It's a fun way to stay fit, make new friends & develop your climbing skills.
Climbing
- Unlike Indoor Bouldering there is a certain amount of skill to be mastered, such as tying in knots & belaying a partner, as well as the climbs being higher than in bouldering. If you are new to climbing or would like a refresher, then this is just for you!! If you‚Äôve climbed before, can safely tie into a harness & can competently belay, then there‚Äôs plenty of choices of top-rope & lead climbing on offer here.
Bouldering
-¬†Instead of tackling long high routes, the 'problems' (as they are referred to) are shorter & focus on technique, balance, body positioning & sometimes power.¬†With the different emphasis, bouldering doesn't have the hassle of climbing with ropes, so it‚Äôs excellent (but not necessarily easier) for newcomers.
Redpoint Birmingham Climbing Centre
has more than 75 lines with over 300 routes, set through some spectacular ground including its notorious 'stalactite'. It even features one of the few indoor 'Yorkshire VS cracks' in the country, to test your jamming skills. The¬†bouldering rooms are just as interesting as its climbing routes, over 200 bouldering problems have been organised into graded circuits to provide something for everyone.
You MUST register via this event page before coming to the centre!
To climb, you will need to:
Complete a
Registration Form
(please arrive early to do this in-person the first time) & pay a Registration Fee:
Annual Registration
is
¬£5
or
Day Registration
is
¬£3
Pay an
Entry Fee
directly to the climbing centre:
Standard Entry
is
¬£12.50
&
Bouldering Only
is
¬£8.50.
Hire
climbing shoes (
¬£3.50
) & a climbing harness (
¬£3.50
) if you don't own your own.
Please see Redpoint's
website
for current prices & note that prices are subject to change.
If you have any questions or need any more information just get in touch with the event leader by clicking on their profile below, or take a look at the
My first climbing event page
for more information.
PLEASE NOTE:
All those attending the event must also be aware of the climbing centre's own terms & conditions of participation & abide by them, along with any instructions given by the centre's staff.

taken & used with permission of
W. Allaway, D. Hanley
&
K. Jones.

Title: Wirral Wandering 2026
Summary:
Hi All
Spring has sprung!
Starting and finishing in Thurstaston, this delightful Wirral walk takes us up to
Thurstaston Common
with its 360 views across the
Dee estuary to the hills of Wales
. We then continue through
Roydon Park
with a quick visit to the
Roodee Mere,
lake before continuing on to Stapledon woods. From here, we make our way up to the
Mariner's Beacon
before a short decent to
Ashton Park
and then into the seaside town of
West Kirby
. We will then go around the marine lake and along
Caldy beach,
heading back to our start point at the Thurstaston visitor's centre where we have the option of tea and cake at one of the two coffee shops on site.
Total distance is
16Km (9 miles
).
There will be some small hills (moderate).
Dogs
- Well-behaved, socialised and under-control dogs are welcome on this event.. Dogs should be kept on a lead whenever this is signposted and whenever we are in the vicinity of sheep and livestock
New Members
- Please feel free to sign up as your first OutdoorLads event. If you have any questions, don't hesitate to message me, or go to the "My First Event" section under "About Us".
If the event is fully booked, please join the waiting list as people frequently drop out during the week before an event and you are likely to get a place on the walk.

Title: BIG20: 3 Nights in the Cheviots Northumberland
Summary:
BIG20 events are our programme to celebrate our 20th birthday year
- showcasing some of the best and most loved locations and venues we've been to in the last 20 years! Come along and on our return trip to one of OutdoorLads' favourite bunkhouses in a remote part of Northumberland for THREE nights, this will be a get away from it all weekend. This is a Friday to Monday trip!
Our venue is located 4¬†miles from the nearest public road, deep into the Cheviots, along the College Valley. It lies less than 1/2¬†mile¬†from the Scottish border, sandwiched between the border ridge and the Cheviot (815m).
It is surrounded by beautifully¬†rounded Northumberland Hills, close to the northern end of the Pennine Way, with deep, wild valleys, and dramatic gullies created at the end of the last ice age.
This will be a remote, away-from-it-all weekend, where phone signals and wi-fi are unlikely, which is a magical chance to connect with OutdoorLads pals and the spectacular scenery that surrounds us. We'll spend two days getting out and exploring on foot - walks are necessarily going to involve some steep climbs and there are no "gentle" options - but you'll be rewarded for your efforts with spectacular views!
The evenings will be filled with hearty, home-cooked meals, and socialising with fellow OutdoorLads - board games and star gazing are likely to be high on the list of evening entertainment. It will be a fantastic weekend of comradery, great food, and genuinely getting out more!
The Hills
The
Cheviot Hills
are a range of rolling hills straddling the Scottish Border¬†with Northumberland. The English section is within the Northumberland National Park.¬†The range includes The Cheviot¬†(the highest hill), plus Hedgehope Hill, Windy Gyle, Cushat Law and Bloodybush Edge.
The hills are sometimes considered a part of the Southern Uplands¬†of Scotland as they adjoin the uplands to the north. Since the Pennine Way¬†runs through the region, the hills are also considered a part of the northern Pennines¬†although they are separated from the Cheviot Hills by the Tyne Gap, part of which lies within the southern extent of the Northumberland National Park.
Some of the gems are in between the hills.
Hen Hole
is one such place and it makes a wonderful route to the top of the Cheviot from the Hostel. It was created at the end of the last ice age, by meltwater, creating a deep gully with waterfalls, leading up to an amazing basin underneath the Cheviot summit. With some very easy scrambles, it makes a fantastic route to highest point in this whole range of hills.
Wildlife in the College Valley (not that we're guaranteed to see it all!)
The valley is well known for its population of
feral goats
and is home to around 150. Rumour has it that they were released in medieval times by the monks on Holy Island. This primitive British breed would have died out completely if they hadn't escaped into the wild. As farming changed there was a swing to foreign breeds which produced more milk. The goats can often be seen on the Newton Tors along the eastern side of the Valley. However they can pop up in the most unexpected of places!¬†Over the years many goats have been re-homed to help manage environments elsewhere in the UK and this has helped to ease the pressure on local vegetation.
Roe deer
are present throughout the valley. Whilst they are beautiful they also bring their own challenges with damage to trees so their numbers are carefully managed.
The valley has a healthy population of
red squirrels
. Hazelnuts are a great source of proteins for the squirrels. With care and quiet you could be lucky and see one of these lovely little mammals.
Adders
, Britain's only venomous reptile are also present in the valley.
Slow worms
, which are really burrowing limbless lizards (commonly mistaken for snakes) are also common. They have been granted protected status along with all other native British reptiles.
Otters
are present along the College and Lambden burns.
There is a good population of
rabbits
,
hares
,
voles
,
fox
,
stoat
and
weasels
. These can be seen throughout the valley.
College Valley Estate has spent a lot of time and effort reintroducing
black grouse
, a marvellous bird at risk of imminent extinction in the UK. Black grouse UK, part of the UK Biodiversity plan, is dedicated to reversing this trend towards extinction. In 1995 the Wilderness above Mounthooly was planted with over 55000 broadleaves. This became the largest new native woodland in England. Black grouse were initially quite successful but bad weather has affected recent breeding seasons and numbers have declined.
There is a healthy and well managed population of
red grouse
on all the heather areas in the valley; shooting for these remarkable birds provides a significant income for the estate. The sound of them telling one to 'go-back, go-back, go-back' is one of the sounds of wilderness areas.
Dogs
. This event is not suitable for dogs.
Photos.
All photos taken by Rob Mitchell, OutdoorLads and used with permission.
IMPORTANT! -¬†Participation Statement
You¬†MUST¬†complete a
Participation Statement
,
in addition
to booking your event space¬†before¬†attending an OutdoorLads event. You only need to complete this Participation Statement once, not for each event you attend.
Difficulty & Distance: Long upland hikes or total relaxation - you choose the difficulty

Title: Stafford - Town and Castle
Summary:
Join me for a winter walk around historic Stafford, including a visit to the castle where there will be time to freely explore the visitor centre and site. For those who would like to join some of our local ODL members for refreshment after the walk, we will be meeting at the Sun Inn which serves a variety of snacks and meals.
Stafford was founded in 913 by Aethelflaed, Lady of the Mercians. As well as being the administrative centre and county town of Staffordshire, it gained prominence through the Middle Ages as an important market town and later as an industrial centre with key industries being shoemaking, engineering and electrical industry.
The Ancient High House is believed to be the largest timber-framed town house in England and was built in 1595 for John Dorrington. After falling into disrepair in the 20th century, it was spared from demolition and saw extensive restoration between 1976-86.
Stafford Castle was built by the Normans on a hilltop to the west of the town in around 1090. Initially made of wood, it was later rebuilt of stone and has been rebuilt twice since. The latest gothic revival dates from the early 19th century and was built atop the earthworks and incorporates much of the original stonework. The final caretakers of the castle moved out in the winter of 1949 as the towers became structurally unsafe. The site was given over to the local authority in 1961 by Lord Stafford and, following works to make the castle remains safe as well as extensive professional excavations the site was opened to the public in 1988.
There is free year-round access to the castle site and we should also be able to access the on-site museum and enter the courtyard. There will be around 90 minutes to explore the castle at your own speed before we walk back into town.
Well-behaved dogs are welcome on this walk.
Your First OutdoorLads Event?
We know that new members in particular like to know in advance more about what an OutdoorLads event will be like.
If this is your first OutdoorLads event, you should check out the information designed specifically for you on the
My First Event
page on the OutdoorLads website. If you have any questions then feel free to message the leader if you have any questions.
What if there is a Waiting List?
If this event is fully booked and you want to attend, just add yourself to the waitlist, because places inevitably become available closer to the date.
Image credits:
All pictures have been taken by the walk leader and permission is given to ODL for their use.
Difficulty & Distance: Approx. 7 miles (11 km) plus free exploration of the Castle and grounds. Mostly level, paved paths with some woodland and field trails.

Title: Boxing Day 2025: Hebden Bridge - Stoodley Pike Circular
Summary:
A circular 7.15 mile (11.5km) walk, with an ascent of 400m.
A post-Christmas day leg-stretcher without being too much of a grueling slog. The route will be a gentle start with a wander along the canal. After a couple of miles we‚Äôll break out in Eastwood and start to make our ascent. The landscape then opens up and (weather-permitting) we will start to enjoy some great views of the landscape. The walk then joins the Calderdale Way where it can be steeper and windy in places, until we reach Stoodley Pike. There are some steps to go up the ‚ÄòPike‚Äô (but it can be very gusty up there so hold on to your hats!). We‚Äôll then make our descent back to Hebden Bridge by walking along Dick‚Äôs Lane to Crow‚Äôs Nest Wood.
Afterwards, for those that want to, there's the option of a drink in one of the local pubs or cafes.
Plan for cold and wet weather!
Slightly earlier start given the shorter days.
Not suitable for dogs given sheep and livestock farms on route.
There are no toilets or shops on the route, so please bring a lunch, drink, and snacks with you.
Main photograph taken by Robert Freeman and published under Creative Commons Licence (CC BY-SA 3.0 DEED) available from:
https://shorturl.at/adqE1
. Other photographs taken by ODL member Richard Waterfield and published with permission.
Difficulty & Distance: Well marked paths and tracks, 7.2 miles, 400m height gain.

Title: Early Spring in the Black Mountains
Summary:
Join Outdoorlads for hiking in the incredible Black Mountains. ¬†Early spring in this region should present us with brisk sun, daffodils, newborn sheep and possibly a bit of snow!
Our accommodation for the weekend will be a basic but comfortable bunkhouse with a large lounge (wood-burning stove with logs included), full kitchen and comfortable bedrooms.
The weekend plans are:
Friday
- plan on arriving after 16:00, find a bed, and get settled in. ¬†Dinner will be a "Build Your Own" Taco Bar with all the fixings!
Saturday
- after a nice cooked breakfast we will head into the Brecon Beacons National Park for a hike.
Potential routes may include this 12km
Dragon's Back Circular,
with a maximum elevation of 810m; or we will attempt to
Tame the Dragon
on this 15.5km hike, along much of the same trails as the Dragon's Back route. ¬†For those interested in a shorter route, this 7km
Mynydd Troed
Circular reaches a maximum elevation of 608m, along a relatively level route. ¬†All three routes leave right from the hostel.
For the cyclists among us, the Lon Las Cymru train is less than a 20 minute ride from the hostel; the
Talgarth - Gospel Pass
loop starts right outside the hostel.
Dinner is of course included and will be determined later.
Sunday
- breakfast will be a leisurely affair, as there is no hurry to depart. ¬†We will all pitch in for the usual "hostel clean-up" and can leave at any time.
Please note that the bunk beds do not have ladders, so a bit of agility may be required. ¬†Additionally, no bedding is provided so you will need to bring everything, including a bottom sheet for a standard sized single bed.
Please bring along whatever drinks and snacks you would like for the weekend; however please note that no food should be kept in the bedrooms, unless it is in a cooler. ¬†There is a small Co-op in Talgarth (8 minute drive) or in Crickhowell (15 minute drive).
Fur-babies are welcome at an additional cost of ¬£10 per night; please email
support@outdoorlads.com
to book and note that no more than 2 dogs are allowed.
OutdoorLads Foundation
Fancy coming along but having a difficult time of it (for whatever reason), and/or finding it hard to justify the expense? Apply for a place on this event through the OutdoorLads Foundation! Nobody apart from staff members will know and we don't need lots of financial info from you either. To apply through the Foundation, you'll need to complete a very short form, which can be found along with more information
here
.

Photos provided
www.unsplash.com
and used by OutdoorLads with full permission.
Difficulty & Distance: Moderate hiking, with a maximum altitude on 810 metres.

Title: Remote Eryri Bunkhouse Weekend 2026
Summary:
Come to the mountains with a sense of adventure and embrace the remoteness!
The
Carneddau
is the northern most mountain range within Eryri National Park (Snowdonia), and is often referred to as the largest area of continuous upland in the UK, south of Scotland. It contains a significant number of
Wales' highest peaks and high mountain lakes
. Most importantly (for the purposes of this event), it also contains our basic and remote accommodation.
The bunkhouse is basic!
Not "basic" in the sense that it's not a hotel... BASIC basic. This is going to be a true mountain adventure, with a degree of challenge and hardship, but with the satisfaction of waking up deep within the Carneddau, far from the nearest road.
Our mountain Cottage is owned by a mountaineering club and is around a
3 mile walk in from the nearest parking area
, just south west of Llyn Eigiau, at about 420m. There are basic cooking facilities, alpine style bunks, a chemical toilet, solar lighting and a cold tap!
The first part of the weekend will involve the logistics of getting us, our gear and our provisions from the car park to the cottage. Nearer the time we will discuss how best to do this, depending upon arrival times, car sharing etc, maybe with two meeting/set-off times, depending on leader availability.
Everyone will need to do a share of the carrying and other chores.
This includes cooking and cleaning, lighting and tending to the coal stove, heating water and "administering" the toilet facilities (this apparently requires the use of a spade!).
To aid your planning we will probably look to meet around 2-3pm on Friday to walk in though as there are only 8 people on this event we can probably be a bit flexible and agree a time.
Aside from our cottage chores, the main part of the weekend will, of course, involve a walk on the Saturday within the mountains which are, quite literally, on our doorstep. There are a number of options which we can do from the front door.
At the end of March it's anyone's guess what the weather will be like. We will need to be prepared for cold and wet conditions, and nearer the time we will study the forecast carefully to enable us to make plans.
Dogs:
sorry,
this event is not suitable for dogs.
Main photos provided by Rugby Mountaineering Club and used with permission.
Other photos by Mark House and Neil Williams, used with permission.
Difficulty & Distance: Mountain walk; mountain living

Title: Early Spring in The Lakes
Summary:
Join us for an early spring weekend in the heart of the Lake District.
Our home for the weekend is a basic but characterful remote bunk house nestled under Glaramara, Great Gable and the Scafell Massif. Our heating is provided by multi-stove burners, so gather round the stove-side after a great day in the mountains and warm your cockles alongside a hot drink and cake.
Depending on leaders available/signed up, we will aim for the mountains for Saturday's main event. From the bunk barn we're able to get up to Scafell Pike (with a strong, experienced group), or the local, spectacular summits of Borrowdale. ¬†If that's not your thing, Keswick is a 20 minute drive away with plenty of history, cafe's and boats on Derwent Water.
Friday night will be the traditional ODL buffet, with breakfast across the weekend and Saturday evening dinner included in you price!
The bunk house is remote, 30 minutes walk from the nearest bus stop, serviced by the 78 bus from Keswick. ¬†Parking is available, but tight, so lift sharing is recommended.
The bunk house sleeps 26 in a room of 18 and a room of 8.
Photos
are used with permission of lav_rich and K Fellfarers
Difficulty & Distance: Depends what you pick to do on the saturday - mountains = difficult, lowland walks = medium, town trip = easy.

Title: Woodland Snow, Scenes of Long Ago, an Inn's Fireside Glow
Summary:
The woods are lovely, dark and deep / But I have promises to keep / And miles to go before I sleep / And miles to go before I sleep.
(Robert Frost:
Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening
)
Unlike the poet and his little horse, we won't have that many miles to go before we sleep, just ten; it won't be evening but daytime; you may or may not have promises to keep; and the woods will probably not be filling with snow. I wouldn't want so much snow that the trains and roads were scuppered, but just the right amount to evoke wonder and nostalgia. We'll probably get no snow and the weather will be mild and murky and the ground muddy, but a man can dream. What we are guaranteed is typical Wealden comfortable countryside, venerable villages, cosy company, and a substantial spread at a lovely pub, The George in Eartham, a venue new to us and eager to have us.
The sights:
Slindon:
A delightful brick and flint village on the southern slopes of the Downs. Only 70 metres up, but with a glorious view across the Sussex Plain to the sea. It is quite unspoilt, so much so that the National Trust has taken charge of the entire place. St Mary's church is over-restored (1866), but there is a lot of value inside. C11 nave walls and C12 chancel. Mediaeval pews. Monument to Sir Anthony St Leger (d.1539), the only wooden effigy in a Sussex church and very well carved. Several fine houses of all ages all around. Nore Folly is just outside the village. A battlemented arch, built 1814, the attached summerhouse built for shooting luncheons is long gone. Grade II-listed.
Eartham:
A tiny, unspoilt village of flint and brick in lovely countryside. Eartham House, which we might glimpse, is by Edwin Lutyens and is from 1905. Not one of his more inspired designs.
Halnaker:
A pleasant straggle of houses along the Roman Stane Street. Old Halnaker House is C14, now ruined, but New Halnaker House is also by Lutyens, of 1938. Very late and heavy. The grounds of the house were used as a filming location for Doctor Who in 1985 for the story
Revelation of the Daleks,
standing in for the planet Necros. The Doctor and Peri ran along then climbed over a flint wall which we'll see.
Boxgrove:
Contiguous with Halnaker and Tangmere, a small and quiet place considering the size of its church. One pretty main street of the now familiar brick, flint and tile houses. Boxgrove Common Quarry became celebrated in 1993 when the tibia and two teeth of the earliest known member of the genus
Homo
found in the UK was uncovered. Back in 500,000 BC
Homo heidelbergensis
was roaming a coastal shoreline that existed at the time, setting up camp and hunting and butchering horse and rhinoceros.
Boxgrove Priory:
The church of St Mary and St Blaise is rather French-looking with its steeply pitched roofs and flying buttresses. Surrounded by modest monastic ruins. Before the Dissolution in 1538 the old nave, lying to the west, served as the parish church. The huge great chancel is now the parish church. The rhythm of column and vault in it is most satisfying. The delicate floral patterns were painted in the vault spaces in the mid-C16. Another treasure of the church is the De la Warre Chantry of 1532. An exquisite gothic box that takes its design from a C15 French Book of Hours. The architecture is late gothic, but the decoration is a mix of gothic and classical, even including some putti supporting the family crests. The vault is carved pendants. The church is rich in other works of art, including a reredos by George Gilbert Scott and stained glass in an Arts and Crafts style.
The bus:
The Stagecoach No. 500 bus leaves Tangmere every 30 minutes at 23 and 53 minutes past. It takes 15 minutes to get to Barnham Railway Station. A single ticket costs ¬£3 and contactless payment is encouraged.
Dogs:
I love having dogs on my walks and this one is quite suitable for them despite it having considerable lane walking, a few stiles, and some fields with livestock. A dog off the lead must be responsive.
The
route
:
We'll take the mixed-use path north along Barnham Lane from Barnham to Walberton, then West Walberton Lane to Fontwell. We'll use the subway under the A27 and wander through Slindon Woods. Having reached the village itself we will take Top Road briefly then a footpath west past Nore Folly. The footpath will continue west to get to Eartham. We will then cross further west to reach the A285 and take a footpath southwest then north to Halnaker Mill which is where we will have lunch. We will descend the hill, have a slight detour past Boxgrove Common and then walk along the A285 (along the pavement), to take The Street south to Boxgrove and its priory. Then using a footbridge over the A27, we will skirt round Tangmere to get to the bus stop.

Title: Bristol Board Games Sunday Social
Summary:
Join us for a Sunday afternoon socialising and playing games
Time to bring out your competitive side with a fun afternoon socialising with other Outdoorlads in¬†Bristol's lovely Chance & Counters games cafe on Gloucester Road.
The cafe has over 850 new and old games to choose from so there should be something for everyone (although I could quite happily play UNO all day). To keep your game-playing energy up the caf√© serves food, soft drinks and alcohol. We usually have lunch there and then start playing (but there's no obligation to eat, if you don't want to!).
I've booked a table at 1pm for eight for four hours. It's ¬£8 each (paid to the cafe at the end of the session). We're a friendly bunch and it's always a good laugh. If you're new to Outdoorlads it's a great way to hang out with and get to know other members but in a cosy indoor setting.

Title: NOTTINGHAM Indoor Climbing ‚Äì TUESDAY - Experienced
Summary:
Join OutdoorLads at Nottingham Climbing Centre
Climbing evenings are held regularly and we tend to go to the local pub ‚Äì The Lion for refreshments and a social gathering afterwards where they have a wide variety of beverages both alcoholic and non-alcoholic.
NOTE: If you are climbing with us for the first time
, please send a note to the
Event Leader
telling them about your experience and goals.
Nottingham Climbing Centre
Nottingham Climbing Centre is equipped with walls and routes to suit all skill levels and groups of climbers, whether you are a novice looking to try climbing for the first time, or an experienced lead climber, you‚Äôll find an area to challenge you. With 28 Top Ropes routes available as well as 24 Lines of Lead climbing for the more advanced individuals. In addition, 6 auto-belays are available, so there is always the opportunity to climb, even if the numbers don‚Äôt match up. The available bouldering walls also provide that extra physical and mental challenge for those looking for something slightly different from rope work. Both Bouldering and Rope Climbing routes range from 4a ‚Äì 8a.
Do I need to be Supervised as a Climber?
If you answer
NO
to any of the following three questions, then you will need to arrange to be supervised and will need to book onto a future beginners event. ¬†If you can answer YES to all these questions, you can sign up to this event as normal:
Can you fit a climbing harness correctly?
Can you tie yourself to the end of a rope using the correct knots?
Can you belay another climber correctly and confidently?
To come along, you will need to register via this event page and to climb you will need to pay an entry fee directly to the climbing centre when you arrive, please see their
website
for up-to-date prices. We ask that all members sign up through the event page to make sure the event leader has all information of the members attending.
To climb at Nottingham Climbing Centre you will need to:
-‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇComplete a climbing waiver for the centre (please arrive early to do this the first time, or better still complete it online before you arrive)
-‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇPay the Lifetime Registration Fee - ¬£6.00
-‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇPay an Entry Fee directly to the climbing centre - ¬£9.50 (ensure you mention ODL)
-‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇHire shoes (if you don‚Äôt have your own) - ¬£3.50*
-‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇHire a harness (again, if you don‚Äôt have your own) - ¬£3.50*
-‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇHire shoes and harness - ¬£6.00*
*Equipment hire charges will be waived for your first visit to the centre!
Can I just come along and boulder?
Absolutely! Most of us do roped climbing, but if you prefer bouldering, you can sign yourself in and do it, as long as you can fill in the climbing centre's form correctly, watch their
safety video
and can answer the simple safety questions at reception on your first visit. Meet the group at the start; some others might be bouldering. We will make sure we come and find you when we have our tea break!
If you have any questions or need any more information just get in touch with the event leader by clicking on their profile below, or take a look at the
My first climbing event page
for more information.
IMPORTANT! - Participation Statement
You MUST complete a
Participation Statement
, in addition to booking your event space before attending an OutdoorLads event. You only need to complete this Participation Statement once, not for each event you attend.
Anyone with COVID-19 symptoms, even if they are extremely mild, or who has recently tested positive for Covid-19, is asked not to attend.

Title: Chester Social
Summary:
A pleasantly civilised social for anyone curious about OutdoorLads, as well as those who already consider it a familiar habit.
The evening is intentionally uncomplicated. A few drinks, some good conversation, and the chance to catch up with existing members while meeting new faces. It‚Äôs also an ideal opportunity to discreetly enquire about the group, upcoming events, and whether we really are as friendly and welcoming as people suggest (spoiler: yes).
It‚Äôs very much a come-as-you-are affair. If the mood takes us, the evening may evolve and wander on elsewhere, but that decision can safely be left until the night itself.
Newcomers, returners, regulars, and the merely intrigued are all warmly encouraged to join us.
Photo credit: all taken by Phil_30.
